awd_titl_txt: Steady stratified water waves and asymptotic models
awd_abstract_narration:
Chen
DMS-1613375

     The theory of water waves is a fascinating topic.  The first comprehensive mathematical understanding of a fluid goes back to Euler in the 1750s, and the equations named after him continue to be the basic model used by mathematicians and engineers today.  Precise and rigorous mathematical analysis of these equations makes it possible to understand the qualitative structures and behaviors of the physical systems they represent.  In this project, the investigator studies: oceanic internal solitary waves, which are recognized to be highly significant components of the dynamics of the coastal sea; the detailed dynamics of wave current interactions, which can help in design of offshore engineering structures as well as in submarine navigation; and the theory of approximate models that shed light on aspects of tsunami waves.  The mathematical results generated from this project are expected to advance the fundamental understanding of ocean waves and currents.  Graduate students are included in the work of the project.

     In this project, (1) existence of large-amplitude stratified solitary waves is established; (2) continuous dependence of surface and internal solitary waves on the streamline densities in a stratified fluid is examined; (3) the stability of solitary waves in some long-wave water wave models as well as a plasma model is studied; (4) the breakdown mechanism of smooth solutions for asymptotic model equations of full water waves is studied; (5) the well-posedness (including existence, uniqueness, and continuous dependence on initial data) of global weak solutions to a class of quasilinear dispersive equations is investigated.  The techniques developed in carrying out this project are expected to be useful for other nonlinear water wave equations.  Graduate students are included in the work of the project.

por.por_cntn:
The theory of the motion of a fluid is a fascinating topic and it can be very complicated. The first comprehensive mathematical understanding of a fluid goes back to Euler in the 1750s, and it continues to be the basic model used by mathematicians and engineers today. The precise and rigorous mathematical analysis makes it possible to understand the qualitative structures of the physical systems and accordingly impact the development of industries having to do with the sea. Some of the aspects in this field include the understanding of the oceanic surface and internal solitary waves, which is recognized to be a highly significant component of the dynamics of the coastal sea; a detailed description of wave current interactions that can help designing offshore engineering structures as well as submarine navigation; and the theory of the approximate models, which reveals the connection relevant to the modeling of oceanic long waves. The  mathematical results generated from this proposed research are expected to provide insight into the fundamental understanding of ocean waves and currents. 

Waves in the open ocean are often observed to be regularly shaped and spaced, propagating at constant speed in a fixed direction. These wave patterns are called the {steady} or {traveling} water waves. Mathematically, steady water waves are solutions of the incompressible free surface Euler system that maintain permanent configuration. Despite extensive study, many aspects of steady waves remain poorly understood. A number of tools now exist for constructing waves in a neighborhood of a known explicit solution, but often the most interesting solutions -- both mathematically and physically | lie outside the perturbative regime. Verifying the existence of these non-perturbative ``large-amplitude" solutions, and understanding their qualitative properties, is far more difficult. 

One classical approach in establishing the existence of large-amplitude solutions is global bifurcation theory which uses topological methods to extend the perturbative solutions as far as possible to a connected set of solutions. Such a theory has proved to be very successful for periodic water waves. However when the underlying equation is posed on an unbounded domain (and the corresponding steady waves carrying finite energy are referred to as the solitary waves), the classical machinery may likely fail since it relies strongly on compactness properties. In this project, we developed a new analytic global bifurcation theoretic approach that relaxes the compactness assumption as in the previous framework, at the price of a new alternative in the global continuation. We further tested this new theory for stratified solitary water waves. By proving some monotonicity property of the waves, a ``compactness or front'' result was proved that totally characterizes how the new alternative may occur. With this we were able to establish the first existence result for large-amplitude stratified solitary waves that exhibit a nontrivial wave-current interaction. 

We then looked into some qualitative study of the solitary waves. For instance we considered the free surface flows generated by certain concentrated disturbances that moves at a constant speed. Mathematically the disturbances can be of the form of point singularities, or can have compact or localized support. We obtained the precise leading-order asymptotics at infinity for the velocity field and free surface, and then applied these to deduce many new interesting qualitative properties of the wave. Another problem we studied regards reconstructing the surface or internal steady stratified waves using pressure data measured at the sea bed. In particular, we proved rigorously that the reconstruction problem is well-posed in the sense that the wave speed, upstream and downstream density and velocity profile, and the pressure on the bed uniquely determine the wave.

We also performed some asymptotic modeling of the free surface wave problem in the shallow-water regime to derive several families of model equations to characterize the dynamics. These model equations provide good approximation to the full water wave system but are easier to study both numerically and analytically. 

Besides the above research projects on the free surface water waves, the PI has also worked on the classical fluid equations like the Euler and Navier--Stokes equations coupled with additional physical effects such as density stratification, elasticity, random noise, etc.. Various analytical properties like the stability, regularity, and energy balance of solutions have been the main topics of investigation. 

To date, this project has produced fourteen pee-reviewed publications and one paper submitted. Besides the research activities, the PI has also participated in several educational programs including organizing undergraduate learning seminar, designing graduate level topic courses, and running working seminars. Three graduate students from UPitt, three exchanging PhD students, and two postdocs were very actively involved in some of the research projects.
